abstract.p: New York Mets players Darryl Hamilton and Turk Wendell discuss playing in New York (S)

block.p: Darryl Hamilton grew up in Louisiana, Turk Wendell in Massachusetts. They had one thing in common: an abiding distaste for and confusion about New York sports fans.
When Hamilton followed sports, he rooted not just for hometown teams but for teams throughout the South. The biggest rivalry Hamilton knew was Southern versus Grambling in college football.
Darryl Hamilton grew up in Louisiana, Turk Wendell in Massachusetts. They had one thing in common: an abiding distaste for and confusion about New York sports fans.
When Hamilton followed sports, he rooted not just for hometown teams but for teams throughout the South. The biggest rivalry Hamilton knew was Southern versus Grambling in college football.
''Southern fans would every once in a while pull for Grambling, and vice versa,'' Hamilton, the Mets outfielder, said. ''But here, uh-uh. I don't see it happening.''
Wendell was an avid Boston Red Sox fan, and said he could not understand the hostility he perceived between Mets and Yankees fans.

''I really hope that the fans of New York just understand it's a New York team, and be happy with that,'' Wendell said. ''Why can't they cheer for both teams? I just hope people appreciate what's going on and enjoy it, rather than splitting up families.''
Hamilton spent more than a decade in the majors before Colorado traded him to the Mets last year.

''Being on the visiting side for so many years, you think it could be a prison term if I'm sent to play for the Mets or the Yankees, because of the fast-paced lifestyle here in New York,'' Hamilton said. ''Everybody likes to get away from the game once in a while. You can't do it here. But when you get here on one of the teams, you realize how important it is and how much fun you have.''

Wendell said: ''I always said the two teams in baseball I never, ever wanted to play for were the Mets and Yankees. I guess the baseball gods got me, but it turned out to be the best thing that ever happened in my career. A lot of people are afraid to play here because the fans put so many expectations on players. For me, it makes me thrive on it.''
